name: Flowerbomb Ruby Orchid Eau de Parfum
about: Fragrance Family:Florals.Scent Type:Warm Florals.Key Notes:Vine Peach, Ruby Orchid, Bourbon Vanilla.Fragrance Description:The heart of this luxurious perfume features two accords: the ruby orchid and the red vanilla bean accord, giving the fragrance a unequivocal sensuality, enhanced by the fresh scent of peach, floral, and vanilla fragrance..About the Bottle:It‚Äòs a ruby pink, diamond grenade fragrance bottle that unleashes a captivating floral fantasy‚Äîa carnal scent fit for a femme fatale..About the Fragrance:Flowerbomb Ruby Orchid is a women‚Äôs perfume inspired by the theatrical tradition of burlesque, where life is a stage. Be the star of the show, express yourself, and embrace your sensuality. When you spray the eau de parfum, you release a magnetic and flowery perfume that pervades every step you take.
ingredients: Alcohol, Parfum/Fragrance, Aqua/Water/Eau, Linalool, Benzyl Salicylate, Benzyl Alcohol, Butyl Methoxydibenzoylmethane, Hydroxycitronellal, Limonene, Coumarin, Methyl Anthranilate, Isoeugenol, Benzyl Benzoate, Citronellol, Citral, C1 17200/Red 33, Ci 60730/Ext. Violet 2.
how_to_use: Suggested Usage:.-Fragrance is intensified by the warmth of your own body. Apply in the creases of your knees and elbows for a longer-lasting, stronger scent. .-After applying, avoid rubbing or dabbing skin. This breaks down the fragrance, causing it to wear off more quickly. .-If you prefer placing fragrance on your wrists, be sure to reapply after frequent hand-washing, as this tends to rinse off the scent. .-Replace fragrance after 12 months. Expired perfumes more than a year old lose the integrity of the original scent... Eau de Toilette or Eau de Parfum?: .The difference lies in the volume of perfume oil. While EDT contains five to nine percent, EDP contains more, usually eight to 14 percent. EDPs, therefore, last longer and smell more intense.

reviews.review_title: Glad I Didn't Purchase the Full-Sizes!
reviews.review_buyer_description: Hazel eyes, Combination skin
reviews.review_text: I bought five 'sample' / travel sizes of Viktor & Rolf perfumes to compare them: Good Fortune, Ruby Orchid (Flowerbomb), Nectar (Flowerbomb) and the Original Flowerbomb. I also bought a sample size of Viktor & Rolf's BonBon Couture perfume.  According to Perfume Descriptions: Ruby Orchid is 'bold,' the original Flowerbomb is an 'explosion of 1000 flowers,' Nectar is a 'potent' perfume, Good Fortune is also described as a 'potent' perfume, and BonBon Couture is described as an 'intensive perfume, stronger than the original BonBon perfume.' Now, I won't get into 'scents' here, but I will say: none of these perfumes were intense, strong, explosive, bold, or potent. In fact, I had to check the packaging to be sure that I hadn't accidentally received the less-potent 'Eau de Toilette' versions of each perfume. I didn't - I received the 'real' / strongest version of all of the perfumes.  Nectar Flowerbomb, Original Flowerbomb, and Ruby Orchid Flowerbomb all smelled nearly identical to me. Out of the 'Flowerbomb' bunch: I'd rate Ruby Orchid first, because it was the strongest-smelling, followed by the Original, because it had some scent to it, followed by Nectar, because it smelled like nothing. But I should note that I had to practically DUMP all three of these Flowerbomb perfumes onto myself to even catch a whiff of scent.  Good Fortune was probably my 'favorite' out of all five - however - if you hate apples and have to take a bite out of five different types of apples to pick the 'least offensive' then I suppose that'd be Good Fortune. It didn't smell 'bad' - it was actually quite pleasant - but when I say it was my 'favorite' it was only because it was just slightly stronger than the Ruby Orchid.  Bonbon Couture was awful - for all of the supposed fragrance notes in it, all I smelled was incense - it was super heavy on the patchouli - yuck. It was definitely the strongest-smelling, but it smelled awful.

reviews.review_title: Fans of the OG 00s Flowerbomb version - get this!
reviews.review_buyer_description: Brown eyes, black hair, Light skin tone, Dry skin
reviews.review_text: Bought this with my own money in-store at Sephora, not incentivized. This is a gorgeous rounded, complex, sweet floral  from the first spray with an overt sugar note overlaying the flowers at the beginning, with a lovely drydown that never goes weird or bitter or alcoholic. It reminds me of the OG Flowerbomb, which was my absolute favorite scent before it got reformulated over the years. So for the nostalgic folks who are wistful for the 00s like me, this is the one to get rather than the current iteration of Flowerbomb-- which has just turned into a very tea/vanilla-heavy scent with poor performance, few floral notes, and that smells absolutely nothing like what made it so popular years ago. Throw is surprisingly good for this, it's immediately at arms-length, especially on clothes, and you get the loveliest wafts of candied flowers throughout the day when you think it's faded. Longevity is decent, at a few hours.

Plus the packaging is so beautiful too! Ruby Orchid does have some of the same DNA as the OG Flowerbomb, but I think Ruby Orchid is stronger than the original, but not in an offensive way. Ruby Orchid has more of a fruity vanilla and warm floral scent, and it smells sweet without being childish or cloying. It‚Äôs a mature sweet perfume without being elderly. This is perfect for spring & summer, but it can be worn all year round too! I‚Äôm good with 2-3 sprays of this and it lasts all day on me! This perfume would be good for all different age groups!

I normally don't like scents that are sweet in this way. They seem girlish, but this one tones it down, and the flower takes the strong note.  I've received compliments, and it definitely lingers.  It will attach itself to clothes you wore, coats included.  Wear with care, but if you like a romantic floral with a touch of sweet, you will love this.  I plan to buy it, only it's so expensive, I will likely stick to the travel size.

reviews.review_buyer_description: Blue eyes, brown hair, Fair skin tone, Combination skin
reviews.review_text: I came here to write a review on this fragrance because I did a blind buy based on my experience with Flower Bomb and the reviews that were already written and I felt like I had been lead astray a bit so I wanted to write the review that I wish I had read. A lot of people say that this is a sweet perfume, and if you're somebody who doesn't love sweet perfumes I can see how one might perceive that (and we all know perfumes can smell different on different people) but if you do like sweet perfumes like Pink Sugar or even the original Flower Bomb then you should be warned that this one isn't like those. This is a darker floriental sort of perfume. It reminds me of a more floral Black Opium or a more sophisticated version of Katy Perry's Killer Queen. The peach is not a juicy body spray peach, it's a deep and subtle vine note with the barest sparkle of something fruity. The vanilla, like the perfume description, is a complex bourbon vanilla like something you would smell in an alcohol bottle more than a baked good. There is a definite floral note in the middle that nods to flower bomb while being distinctly something new. Like most good perfumes, this one combines into something unique and reading the notes/accords in the description won't give the actual scent any justice. The perfume has burlesque vibes to it, imagine something heady and sexy like sweeping back a velvet curtain as you slink onto the stage of a smokey cabaret. It has an average lasting power and sillage. I got it for a specific event where I was cosplaying as a conflicted character and I think this helped me get into the headspace for that. I enjoy the scent and will use this bottle, but wouldn't buy it again.

It does resemble Nectar a bit in how it‚Äôs structured but without the patchouli base note, I think I like this even more. It‚Äôs the perfect summer fragrance. reviews.review_buyer_description: Brown eyes, brown hair, lightMedium skin tone, Combination skin
reviews.review_text: I am a Flowerbomb finatic. I can‚Äôt stand to wear what everyone else is wearing, but flowerbomb is just a signature in my collection, and always will be, just like black opium. I have already purchased this flowerbomb ‚ÄúRuby orchid‚Äù right when it dropped, then took it back. I wear more ‚Äúniche‚Äù fragrances these days, but I still have my day 1 signature scents AKA Flowerbomb & Black Opium. Well, I‚Äôm not big into designer perfume anymore (I‚Äôm into niche) but the flowerbomb line always has a special place in my heart. I went into Sephora today to get me a new bottle of the original ‚ÄúFlowerbomb‚Äù because it‚Äôs almost empty. I ended up purchasing ‚ÄúRuby orchid‚Äù instead and ALSO for the second time! I compared flowerbomb on one scent tester, then compared Ruby orchid, and honestly, Ruby orchid gives flowerbomb a ‚Äúbite‚Äù if you will. The ruby orchid, red vanilla bean, peach, and bourbon vanilla will rock your socks. The original has patchouli in it (which I adore) and ruby orchid does not. Theirs something about ruby orchid that makes me love it even more than flowerbomb, and I do believe it‚Äôs that bourbon vanilla in it. First spray is Ruby orchid and peach, then once it settles into the skin you have that vanilla bourbon which is off the chain. I don‚Äôt collect designer anymore, but flowerbomb line always has a place on my fragrance tray. Ruby orchid just happened to beat the original today lol. I also bought this once already, and now here I am again buying it again. That must be saying something right? This is beautiful honestly. Same scent profile as the original, but has a kick to it that I love.

reviews.review_buyer_description: Blue eyes, brown hair, Light skin tone, Normal skin

reviews.review_text: Surprisingly really like this! Never been a huge fan of OG Flowerbomb or even its other flankers because of how much of a headache it caused and how sickeningly sweet it got. Ruby Orchid though is very nice and just the right amount of sweetness. It's a bit on the softer side but the Flowerbomb DNA in the dry down grounds this scent and prevents it smelling too generic. It's soft and pretty but also flirty and very intriguing. The peach and vine notes really pair well with the Flowerbomb DNA and makes it more versatile to wear imo. For longevity, I need to test this a bit more but it doesn't seem to last as long as I would like on the skin (3-4 hours). But on clothes, this lasts for a very long time. Imo worth it, really like this!

Also just 2 sprays work, but the fragrance disappears in 5 hours or so. Another complaint about this perfume is the price, it is a little pricy when I compare it with some similar, not so long lasting but fab perfumes I own. Overall, I did like the perfume, and it is more of a special occasion perfume for me not an everyday wear. But might actually consider buying it again if the price comes down a bit!   P.S. reviews.review_title: My new little black dress of perfumes
reviews.review_buyer_description: Brown eyes, black hair, Light skin tone, Dry skin
reviews.review_text: I recieved a complimentary bottle of this amazing perfume for my honest opinion about it. Here it is. This perfume was touted as a Fruity Gourmand perfume. A fruity bent, gourmand level scent. Right on the fruity, double on the gourmand, but that ignores the lovely almost heavenly, and seriously not too cloying flower notes. I was quite terrified when I got this bottle. I was afraid that it would be so flowery (with a name like Flowerbomb, can you blame me?). It is not overpowering floral, or perfumy.   This scent is so sweet and delicate, the lower notes make it sexy and sensual, and the fruity notes maje it light and fun. I can truly say that whether I wear it to a Wedding, Date, Lunch with my Mother or a Funeral, I will be appropriately perfumed. It is the little black dress of petfumes.
